### Description

## The current task distribution logic problem
1. Does not consider the factors of worker load and available memory
2. Distribute only one task to workers at a time

##Optimize
1. Batch assignment of tasks
2. Workers that are overloaded will not distribute tasks for the time being
3. The number of distributed tasks refers to the memory size available to the current worker

## Flowchart
![task batch distribution](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13765310/179178765-b4e6d56e-9a69-476a-b2c6-13234ed678e7.jpg)

I think we can treat it as a [knapsack problem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knapsack_problem), and use the Hungarian algorithm to solve it.

1. Worker available memory as backpack capacity
2. Task memory is used as item weight
3. Task priority as item value (Or other reference values as values)

But there is an assumption:
1. We know the task memory usage

I don't know if that complicates the problem.
Now ds has a `LowerWeightRoundRobin` selector, it will filter the busy and abnormal worker, you can see the logic of `HeartbeatTask`.

> > I think we can treat it as a [knapsack problem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knapsack_problem), and use the Hungarian algorithm to solve it.

I'm sorry I got it wrong, it's more of a generalized assignment problem.

> Hi @jieguangzhou, this looks good to me. For some users who are not willing to spend some time picking up python but do have tons of workflows to generate, yaml is a better approach than dragging and connecting tasks through the UI. Just curious, why do you want this feature? Are you a `yaml lover`? ðŸ˜„

If we can use YAML to manage workflows, it might make it easier for engineers to manage workflows and do version management. Git can be used to manage and share workflows.
In addition, after communicating with some overseas engineers, I found that some engineers prefer to use YAML to manage programs, which I think is also suitable for me.
I think `yaml` is better than `TOML` or `JSON` for this scenario.
